title: 114_hr5256
content: The Act titled "Expanding DHS Overseas Passenger Security Screening and Vetting Operations Act" establishes a comprehensive strategy and implementation plan for DHS operations abroad. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a five-year strategy for international programs to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The strategy should include specific risk-based priorities and a method for determining new or expanded programs based on resource constraints. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a five-year strategy for international programs to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The strategy should include specific risk-based priorities, alignment of resource allocations with strategic priorities, a common reporting framework for cost data, and considerations for existing operations and personnel deployment. The strategy for international programs must include analysis of personnel deployment, impacts on domestic operations, regional coordination, and barriers to program implementation. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to submit an annual implementation plan to Congress based on the strategy for international program expansion. This plan should be included with the President's budget request for the following fiscal year through fiscal year 2022. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit an annual implementation plan to Congress based on the strategy for international program expansion. The plan should include details on each international program's goals, planned deployments of personnel, and resource allocation per location. Additionally, there should be a plan to ensure appropriate personnel deployment outside the United States. The implementation plan required under paragraph (1) must ensure oversight and support for international operations, coordination, and communication abroad. It should be submitted in unclassified form with the possibility of a classified annex if deemed necessary by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The U.S. Customs and Border Protection staffing expansion is addressed in Section 3. The Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection is required to increase the number of officers and Agriculture Specialists by 1,000 and 300 respectively by September 30, 2017 and 2018. The Secretary of Homeland Security must provide periodic reports to the Committee on Homeland Security of the House. The Secretary of Homeland Security must provide information to the House and Senate Committees on Homeland Security regarding the implementation status of increasing officers and Agriculture Specialists as required. Expansion of the Visa Security Program is outlined in Section 4. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a plan within 180 days to expand the Visa Security Program to at least 50 U.S. diplomatic and consular posts within five years. The plan should prioritize posts based on risk, volume, personnel needs, costs, and security concerns. Additionally, the Secretary must provide periodic reports on the program. The Secretary of Homeland Security must provide periodic reports to the Committee on Homeland Security regarding the implementation of the Visa Security Program expansion plan. SEC. 5. PRE-ADJUDICATED THREAT RECOGNITION AND INTELLIGENCE OPERATIONS TEAM (PATRIOT) PROGRAM EXPANSION. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a deployment plan for the PATRIOT program to 50 US diplomatic and consular posts issuing visas, detailing personnel, costs, security concerns, and timelines for deployment. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to implement a plan for the deployment and operation of the PATRIOT program at US diplomatic and consular posts issuing visas. Periodic reporting on the implementation progress must be provided to the relevant congressional committees upon request. SEC. 6. IMMIGRATION COOPERATION PROGRAM AUTHORIZATION. A new Immigration Cooperation Program is established within U.S. Customs and Border Protection to cooperate with foreign authorities, air carriers, and security employees at foreign airports to identify individuals who may be inadmissible to the United States or pose a security risk. SEC. 7. INTERNATIONAL TRUSTED TRAVELER PROGRAMS MODERNIZATION. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a plan within 180 days of the enactment of the Act to expand participation in trusted traveler programs. The plan includes strategies for increasing public awareness, analyzing barriers to expansion, and assessing impacts on staffing and resources. The plan includes strategies for increasing public awareness and analyzing barriers to expansion of trusted traveler programs, as well as assessing impacts on staffing and resources. Additionally, it requires an assessment of measures to address potential risks and vulnerabilities, and an analysis of the facilitation and security benefits from increased participation in trusted traveler programs. SEC. 8. The Comptroller General will review and report on the security screening process for nonimmigrant visas within 180 days of the Act's enactment. This includes visa eligibility determination, security screening, background checks, and agency coordination. SEC. 9 defines terms. SEC. 9 defines the term "international program" as operations of U.S. Customs and Border Protection or U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement abroad. SEC. 10 authorizes $250,000,000 for fiscal years 2017 and 2018 for this Act.
